The '''April 6 Youth Movement''' is an [[Egypt]]ian [[Facebook]] group started by [[Ahmed Maher]] and [[Ahmed Salah]] in Spring 2008 to support the workers in [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra]], an industrial town, who were planning to strike on April 6.<ref name=wired>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.wired.com/techbiz/startups/magazine/16-11/ff_facebookegypt |title= Cairo Activists Use Facebook to Rattle The '''April 6 Youth Movement''' ''({{lang-ar|Ø­Ø±ÙØ© Ø´Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ 6 Ø£Ø¨Ø±ÙÙ}})'' is an [[Egypt]]ian [[Facebook]] group started by [[Ahmed Maher]] and [[Ahmed Salah]] in Spring 2008 to support the workers in [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra]], an industrial town, who were planning to strike on April 6.<ref name=wired>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.wired.com/techbiz/startups/magazine/16-11/ff_facebookegypt |title= Cairo Activists Use Facebook to Rattle Regime |date=October 20, 2008 |first=David |last=Wolman |journal=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |publisher=[[CondÃ© Nast Publications]] |accessdate=February 15, 2008}}</ref><ref name=nat>{{cite news|title=Parliament is burning, and the watching crowd is laughing |first=Hamida |last=Ghafour |date=August 25, 2008 |work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]] |publisher=[[Martin Newland]]|url=http://www.thenational.ae/article/20080825/OPINION/235828560/1080&template=opinion |accessdate=February 15, 2008}}</ref><ref name=dne>{{cite news|url=http://dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=15325 |work=[[Daily News Egypt]] |title=Protestors say Agrium plant is like Nazi gas chambers |first=Abdel-Rahman |last=Hussein |date=July 27, 2008 |publisher=Egyptian Media Services |accessdate=February 15, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|work=Daily News Egypt |title=April 6 youth detainees still in custody despite release order|publisher=Egyptian Media Services |first=Sarah |last=Carr |date=July 30, 2008 |url=http://dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=15407 |accessdate=February 15, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=16577 |work=Daily News Egypt|title=Emaar accused of culpability in Duweiqa rockslide|publisher=Egyptian Media Services |first=Abdel-Rahman |last=Hussein |date=September 18, 2008 |accessdate=February 15, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=In Focus: The Dilemma of Egyptâs Liberals |first=Khalil |last=Al-Anani |date=September 2, 2008|publisher=Egyptian Media Services |work=Daily News Egypt|url=http://dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=16173 |accessdate=February 15, 2008}}</ref>
Activists called on participants to wear black and stay home the day of the strike. Bloggers and citizen journalists used [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]], [[Flickr]], blogs and other new media tools to report on the strike, alert their networks about police activity, organize legal protection and draw attention to their efforts.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.arabmediasociety.com/?article=692|work=Arab Media & Society|title=Core to Commonplace: The evolution of Egypt's blogosphere|publisher=American University of Cairo |first=Courtney |last=Radsch |date=Fall 2008 |accessdate=February 15, 2008}}</ref>
Activists called on participants to wear black and stay home the day of the strike. Bloggers and citizen journalists used [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]], [[Flickr]], blogs and other new media tools to report on the strike, alert their networks about police activity, organize legal protection and draw attention to their efforts.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.arabmediasociety.com/?article=692|work=Arab Media & Society|title=Core to Commonplace: The evolution of Egypt's blogosphere|publisher=American University of Cairo |first=Courtney |last=Radsch |date=Fall 2008 |accessdate=February 15, 2008}}</ref>
